text: I always say to talented people in sports (talented, as in they  prooved themeselves in some competition or in a team as doing something that stands out). Please respect your talent! With the explanation that they need to nurture their talent and work hard to really become someone that will be recogniezed within their sport. Whatever will be the outcome you know that you did your best and that you will carry with you all life. I didnÂ´t really respect my own talent. I found several reasons for not pushing through. Winning and knowing exactly what I needed to actually do to move to the next step i couldnÂ´t follow through. My biggest talent was grit, until it wasnÂ´t any more. I had a hard time accepting and figuring out how it was I came to a situation where I did not want it as much as before. How injuries and other stuff ended up taking my grit away instead of growing stronger. Still puzzled but I learnt over the passed 25 years that the environment didnÂ´t suit me. Individual sport but travelling with a team that casused rivalry within the team. I actually made more friends outside my own team over the years with whom I could share meaningful discussions and views of culture and life. (ok it wasnÂ´t all that deep but deep enough and much more rewarding than fighting within my own team and not having especially interesting conversations over days and months in training and competition all over the world). Not being given the space to cheerish moments of culture and history while travelling the world doing sports, is really missed opportunities. Unfortunately the time after sports has been a roller coaster of me trying to be the best I can but also not respecting the time and strategy it takes to reach goals in civilian life. I had success if itÂ´s measured in well paid and otherwise rewarding job positions, but only to feel I did not really earn it and never really finding myself. Always having that lost sporting career at the back of my mind. Finally at 45 I can truly enjoy life, family, work and everything else that is presented to me in everyday life. Maybe what Federer misses is that not everyone will have back up from family, maybe even worse, only pressure. To manage pressure from family and juggling an idea of making career choices that are not really accepted by family can be draining. To the point that you become half of what you really are and actually can achieve. It all adds up to something good and it adds to your character whatever the outcome of the experience will be. It could be a bad experience but it all adds up to make you a broad minded person with great understanding of many things rather than holding tight to the comfort of being great at your profession. Nothing bad with being good at your profession but the world and companies need people that are more than their profession and more than their specifik knowledge. text: My best friend from my childhood, Yayo, passed away 2 days ago at the young age of 61.  He was an athlete. Judo. Karate. Boxing. Swimming. And Tennis. I was only drawn to running long distance and boxing. I'm right handed. Yayo was left handed. So after getting punched plenty on the face with his right jab, he suggested I switch to a left hand stance. I did. Took a while to get used to it but I did it. It worked great. It became second nature.  When we were about 12 Yayo invited me to play tennis with him. Never held a tennis racket before. He was very patient with me and was I think more eager than I to teach me how play tennis so I could also enjoy something he enjoyed a lot.  Regretfully, my family had to move to another city and would only see him on holidays. We remained best of friends until his passing. Even though I did not continue with tennis, I loved watching a great match. I still do. When Federer came into the scene I inmediately was drawn to him.  The way he played was absolutely marvelous. But what drew me more to him was his demeanor. Even if some people who know him personally would argue that it is all a farse, an act, I want to believe that it is not so. The guy acts so humbly in defeat but most importantly in victory. That's how my best friend Yayo was. Everytime I sit in front of the tv and watch a tennis match I think about Yayo. Every time I hear Federer speak I'm reminded of Yayo's humility and generosity. Rest in peace my dear friend.

author: @wallaceyallup4036
text: Attacking your opponent's strength, to break them, and gain confidence. I can't believe how much Roger and I have in common, the mindset, the journey to getting to be better. I too had this mindset of attacking player's forehand (which for most, is their strength), versus attacking the backhand (which mostly is less consistent or powerful than the forehand), and it was taking what is a tougher road to finding greatness. Tougher I found because I'd lose many points, games, matches because I was on a journey to becoming a more confident player, and it would happen much later on, than a few months away. Celebrating the little victories along the way, the feeling of winning just 1 or 2 more points per game even if you lost the game, is rewarding. The same goes for winning a service game, when going at their stronger side (mostly the forehand), keeping the mindset that all the while you're competing with your opponent, but at the same time, you're challenging yourself to do just a bit better with each point. There's a lot of fail that happens along the way, and how you deal with it, and carrying forward is what defines your character on court, maybe even in life. IMHO, I feel that is how you build the confidence and mental toughness. Personally, as an athlete, that ran 5:15 splits in 5k and 10k races, threw 2 hitters with 19 Strike outs at 18 years old, went years without double faulting, ever., practicing strokes up against the wall for 2-3 hours per day as a college kid, serving 300 balls a day outside of tennis practice, so that I could feel confident enough to hit anywhere I wanted on the court (on my demand), only to be as relentless in life off of the court to get what I wanted, was my resolve. Let me tell you something: any of the strengths/tools you use in life, you can be rest assured, that positive mindset happened and grew in your sport(s), one point at time, game at time, match etc.. A saying I love, anything want to learn about how to deal with everyday living, you can learn on the tennis court, playing competitive tennis. I love this game so, so much. I gave it to my Son. I loved watching him play, grow as a person, and as a high-performing athlete in it. In my adult years, and as I found The Maestro, The King, The GOAT, I watched his matches and replays, and enjoyed it, still do to this day, here it is 23 years later. I still play, and I still channel RF when I need to dig deep and focus. My zone is peRFect when I know I am out there playing to be better than the shot before, the day before, match before. It's important to keep growing, in my personal opinion. Glass is half full, always. I love this game. I love who Roger Federer is. What a speech he gave, right? Oh, and, Congratulations to you 2024 Grads, and to Dr. Roger Federer, also Class of 2024. Bravissimo!
